hey, i'm trying to learn the piano parts for this one song and i'm not sure how to read piano tabs. i've been playing piano for 11 years and i've never learned how. so if anyone knows. please let me know. its for piano...not guitar.

piano tabs? I'm not sure what you mean? I assume you've been reading music if you've been playing for 11 years. I've never heard of piano tabs though. Do you have an example image or something? Does it look like a guitar tab? Does it give the chord?

piano tabs? I'm not sure what you mean? I assume you've been reading music if you've been playing for 11 years. I've never heard of piano tabs though. Do you have an example image or something? Does it look like a guitar tab? Does it give the chord?

 I was thinking the same thing. If you've been playing for 11 years, you must be able to rtead music, so I'm not sure what the problem is.
Well I know guitar tabs have something to do with chords, so I didn't know if there was some other notation I didn't know about with piano "tabs" that showed the chords.

Well I know guitar tabs have something to do with chords, so I didn't know if there was some other notation I didn't know about with piano "tabs" that showed the chords.

 No, guitar tablature is a way of representing what string is picked at what fret. It doesn't have anything to do with chords. What I believe you are thinking of is where chords are shown above lyrics to show how to play a song. That is something of a musical cheat sheet, which guitarists use all the time, but is not tablature. This can be used to play songs on piano (or any other instrument for that matter), but is not specific to piano.

 I know what you're talking about, I just always thought the guitar symbol had something to do with the chord (well I mean obviously it has SOMETHING to do with it, but that's not what I meant), not the individual strings played. Guess you learn something new every day. :)

 I'm going to assume that you mean the melody is written out with chord symbols above the measures. 
 
 Is this what you mean? Above the measures you see symbols like: CM = C major, cm= c minor, CM6=C major chord, first inversion (bottom note, the C, is played in the soprano). Or do you see Roman numerals like IV, V, VI? Those are the...
 
 Oh, geesh, go get a theory book. :) Or you can go to http://www.musictheory.net for help with this. Good luck!
